Award.AwardTitle: Functional Analysis of Signaling Pathways Controlling Limb Regeneration
Award.AbstractNarration:
Urodele amphibians (newts and salamanders) are unique throughout the animal kingdom in their ability to perfectly regenerate whole organs such as limbs, brains and the heart. For example, if the limb is amputated anywhere along its length a perfect replacement will regenerate in about 1-2 months and this regenerate will contain the bones, cartilage, joints, muscles, nerves, blood vessels and skin that were originally there and all in the exactly the same relationship to each other so that the limb will work again. The goal of this project is to determine how growth factors and signaling molecules drive this process. It has long been known that the nerves supply a factor that stimulates the proliferation of the regenerating cells in the limb, and several candidates have been identified recently. This project functionally tests each of these candidates in a novel assay based on gene expression in the wound epidermis. The identification of a factor that stimulates proliferation would have a huge impact on mammalian systems where the lack of proliferation is the major impediment to tissue regeneration. In addition to the nerve factor, two additional signaling pathways are utilized to guide the regenerative process. These will also be examined using the latest gene knockout techniques to determine how these pathways interact with other known signals. This project will impact several scientific communities, and the public at large because regeneration has huge public appeal. Examples of this interest include that fact that these recent axolotl regeneration studies were highlighted in TV programs and other public media, and received public acclaim. Additionally, this project includes specifically-designed mini-research projects that involve 4-6 undergraduates per year, and promotes active involvement of under-represented minorities and women.


The first part of this project concentrates on the function of the apical epidermis that forms after limb amputation as a crucial regulator of regeneration. Transcriptomic analysis has identified the limb-specific genes expressed in this apical epidermis, including Wnt, BMP and FGF - as well as two novel pathways: IGF and RA. These new pathways will be examined by inhibition using antisense morpholinos, pharmacological inhibition and Crispr/Cas9 targeted mutagenesis to identify interactions with other pathways by qPCR and in situ hybridization. The transcriptional network downstream of RA signaling will also be examined by RNA-Seq to identify targets of this signaling molecule. The second objective is to discover the molecular basis of the neurotrophic control of limb regeneration. A novel approach will be used to screen 12 potential neurotrophic factors for their effect on gene expression in the apical epidermis in vitro since the apical epidermis is the primary target of the nerve. Included in this screen are 7 novel neurotrophic factors that were identified in a microarray for secreted factors from sensory nerves. Successful candidates will be taken further using in vivo analyses including expression patterns during limb regeneration and over-expression in transgenic animals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has considerably advanced our knowledge and understanding of several aspects of limb regeneration in salamanders. In one aspect, the neurotrophic control of limb regeneration, we have identified the important factor which the nervous system produces to control proliferation during limb regeneration and begun to study its molecular basis of action. This identification comes 90 years after the first revelation of the control that the nervous system plays in limb regeneration and will also be of great significance to other vertebrate regenerating systems because it has been hypothesized in the past that the reason why other vertebrate limbs cannot regenerate is because they do not have enough of this neurotrophic factor. These ideas can now be tested.

In another aspect, interactions between the IGF, FGF and RA signaling pathways have been identified thanks to our development of multiplexed fluorescence in situ hybridization which has allowed for the simultaneous visualization of the expression patterns of multiple genes in limb blastemas. In this was potential interactions between signaling pathways can be identified more rapidly and we have identified such interactions for these three pathways.

In a third aspect, the molecular basis of positional information controlled by RA in the regenerating limb, we have identified the major gene players which are responsible for respecifying the pattern of the regenerating limb by RA. They include other signaling pathways such as the FGF pathway and interesting cell matrix genes and toll-like receptor genes revealing the roll of cell surface receptors/matrix properties in the control of positional information. This may have significance for understanding why other amphibian limbs (frogs and toads) cannot regenerate and perhaps mammals as well – perhaps they cannot re-waken their positional information network.

 

In addition to these conceptual advances we have made very significant methodological advances for the visualization of gene expression in limb blastemas using multiplexed fluorescence in situ hybridization which allows for simultaneous expression analysis of several genes at one time followed by light sheet microscopy to produce 3-D imaging (see figure below). This advance permits a large increase in the rate at which gene expression patterns can be analysed as this process was previously undertaken one gene at a time and furthermore the relationship and potential interactions between genes can be clarified with this simultaneous visualization technique.

 

The left image shows a tissue section of the wound epidermis of the regenerating limb. The three genes are uromodulin (yellow), keratin 5 (blue), and wnt5a (magenta). The right image shows a developing limb bud of an axolotl and the expression of three signalling genes.

 

This project has also provided a very significant amount of training, education and scientific interactions for the graduate students and undergraduates on the grant. They have attended a total of 8 conferences, they have presented a total of 26 posters or talks at these meetings, they have been teaching assistants for 7 semesters. The PIs on the grant have attended 7 conferences to present the grant data, been teaching faculty on courses 6 times, given 21 seminars and talks and published 9 papers on the data that has been generated in the grant.

There has also been a good deal of outreach into the community with 4 public media/film contributions, 1 high school presentation and 2 museum presentations.
